standfirst:
The MP walked out of a television interview on Thursday after being asked about his legal battle with a Chinese business partner."Don't talk to me about allegations and bullshit," the Palmer United party leader told Sarah Ferguson on ABC TV's 7.30 program. The mining magnate refused to be drawn on the court battle, saying there were no proceedings against him personally. "I'm not answering any more, so goodbye ... see you later," he said, pulling out his earpiece and walking out of the studio.
• Read the full story
headline: Clive Palmer walks out of TV interview - video

standfirst: A video filmed at Barcelona airport shows two planes almost crashing on the runway. An Airbus 340 is shown crossing the runway at El Prat Airport in Spain as a flight from Moscow is coming in to land. Seeing the Airbus in its path, the pilot of the Boeing 767 from Russia aborts the landing. The plane then lands safely on the runway shortly afterwards
headline: Airbus 340 and Boeing 767 nearly collide at Barcelona airport - video

standfirst: South African sprinter accused of murdering his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp could be just weeks away from learning his fate
headline: Oscar Pistorius's defence team plans to rest case on Tuesday

standfirst: In court, Oscar Pistorius's  lawyer, Barry Roux, says he has finished calling witnesses but adds that some have chosen not to testify because of the publicity. The prosector requests and is granted an order that no publication of the heads of argument can take place until argument has commenced in court. The athlete is accused of killing his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp, by firing through a closed lavatory door at his home last year following an argument. Pistorius says he mistook her for an intruder. The final arguments are scheduled for 7-8 August
headline: Pistorius defence team closes case in his murder trial – video

standfirst: Tech-enthusiast Emanuele Costa believes the digital currency could transform Kyrgyzstan’s remittances, which make up a third of the country's economy. EurasiaNet reports
headline: Kyrgyzstan bitcoin experiment promises migrant workers big savings

standfirst: Pontiff makes strongest condemnation yet of paedophile priests and senior clergy who obfuscated rather than punished
headline: Pope Francis lambasts Catholic bishops who helped cover up child abuse

standfirst: Infrastructure projects and provisions to lure foreign investment among key measures aimed at rejuvenating economy
headline: Narendra Modi's administration unveils first budget for India

standfirst: We asked Muslim bloggers to tell us their experiences of living as a Muslim in the UK today. Do you agree? Share your thoughts and experiences.
headline: What is it like to be a Muslim in Britain today?

standfirst: UK chancellor and foreign secretary William Hague meet new PM to strike multimillion-pound defence and construction deals
headline: George Osborne to meet Narendra Modi on trade trip to India

standfirst: Woman who promised to rekindle South African dream says she wants to work on making society more just and prosperous
headline: Mamphela Ramphele announces she is quitting party politics

standfirst: From surveillance laws and Brazil's destiny to early erotic graffiti and Britons falling off their bikes – a roundup of the week's news
headline: 10 things we learned this week

standfirst: Heavy wind and rain batter the areas of Nakagusuku and Kagoshima as Typhoon Neoguri reaches Japan's main islands. Wind speeds reached up to 162 kph (100mph) on Wednesday, leaving two people dead. Forecasters said the storm is weakening but warned of flooding as a result of continuing heavy rain
headline: Typhoon Neoguri moves north across Japan - video

standfirst:
Rolling coverage of election day in the world's third-largest democracy, as Indonesia decides its next president

  • Read the end-of-day summary
  • Jokowi and Prabowo both claim victory
  • Five reasons why Indonesia's presidential election matters
headline: Indonesia election 2014: Jokowi and Prabowo both declare victory - as it happened

standfirst:
Polls put outsider Joko Widodo, running on an anti-corruption platform, ahead but ex-general Prabowo also claims mandate

• Indonesia elections: all the day's events as they happened
headline: Jokowi and Prabowo both claim victory in early Indonesian election results

standfirst: Group of 63 women and children abducted from three villages in June walk for almost 24 hours before Nigerian authorities alerted
headline: Scores of Boko Haram captives escape

standfirst:
Five people refused to testify owing to media attention, says defence as it wraps up its case in Paralympian's murder trial

• Following all of the trial developments for Tuesday 8 July
headline: Oscar Pistorius's lawyers hint at appeal over witnesses deterred by TV coverage

standfirst: Minimum working age will remain 14 but government office will be able to authorise employment of children as young as 10
headline: Bolivia to allow 10-year-olds to work

standfirst: Eugene de Kock was refused parole today in a case that has divided South Africa. But his imprisonment is meaningless while the real villains are still at large, says Justice Malala
headline: Why South Africa should release apartheid's 'Prime Evil' assassin

standfirst: We're on the look out for new partners on the Africa network. Specialist journalists, bloggers and news organisations who know the continent best. Interested? We'd love to hear from you
headline: Join the Guardian’s Africa Network

standfirst: Footage from a river monitoring camera captures  a landslide sweeping through the town of Nagiso, a mountainous area of central Japan. As it flattened homes, it killed a boy and injured three members of his family, bringing the total dead to three. Rivers were swelled by rains from typhoon Neoguri which brought down boulders on the town, in the Kagoshima prefecture. Neoguri has weakened to a tropical storm but wind speeds remain at 78mph (126kph)
headline: Typhoon Neoguri: 12-year-old boy killed by landslide in Japan – video report

standfirst: Preliminary results due but many fear political crisis over disputed poll could destabilise country and spark violence
headline: Afghans await presidential election results amid fraud claims

standfirst: Despite restrictions and censorship in some countries, the internet is becoming an increasingly powerful tool around the region. Here's how online freedoms compare:
headline: From Bamboo to E-stonia: social media in the post-Soviet states

standfirst: Daniel Chong was left in a San Diego cell for five days without food or water in 2012, and drank his own urine to survive
headline: DEA agents shirked responsibility over student in cell, report finds

standfirst: Li Biyun, accused of brandished a knife at guards who stopped her leaving, says she was trying to defend herself
headline: Chinese activist on trial for trying to visit hospital while under house arrest

standfirst: Kiev aims to win back control of Donetsk and Luhansk as rebel groups gather in big cities after abandoning smaller strongholds
headline: Ukraine and pro-Russian rebels square up for showdown

standfirst: A nation waits to learn whether it will be ruled by reformist Joko Widodo or hardline ex-general Prabowo Subianto
headline: Indonesia: rivals both claim victory in presidential election

standfirst: Once a dictatorship, now the world's third-largest democracy, the 90% Muslim country is poised to take a step forward
headline: Five reasons why Indonesia's presidential election matters

standfirst: Scheduled talks with John Kerry over Ukraine and Iran to be overshadowed by concerns over recent espionage allegations
headline: Germany demands public promise from US to end spying

standfirst: The Netherlands' goalkeeper, Tim Krul, made a short but spectacular World Cup debut coming on seconds before the end of the quarter-final against Costa Rica to save two penalties in a shootout and give the Dutch a victory. He did his best to put off the Costa Rica penalty-takers, leaping about on his line and approaching them as they placed the ball. Some have criticised Krul's antics as unsporting, saying the referee should have been stricter with the goalkeeper
headline: World Cup 2014:  Netherlands' Krul defends penalty antics - video

standfirst: Recently elected leader accepts invitation to Washington after being denied visa in 2005 over sectarian violence in Gujarat
headline: Indian prime minister Narendra Modi to visit United States

standfirst: The archbishop of Canterbury plans to force legislation through if the General Synod does not accept female bishops
headline: Church of England women bishops: archbishops will overrule synod

standfirst: Spokesman says comedian will follow 'aggressive outpatient programme' while suit filed Thursday focuses on tiredness of truck driver
headline: Tracy Morgan leaves rehab and sues 'reckless and wanton' Walmart over crash

standfirst: Man surrenders to police after two adults and three children died at the scene, with a fourth child later dying in hospital
headline: Spring shooting: six killed in suburban Houston including four children

standfirst: Surge in number of unaccompanied children crossing border from Central America poses a humanitarian challenge
headline: Rio Grande border to US sees 57,000 young migrants in nine months

standfirst: All air passengers must demonstrate that mobiles and other devices are powered up and functioning as Department for Transport tightens airport security
headline: Britain follows US in banning powerless electronic devices from flights

standfirst: Super-typhoon Neoguri, with gusts of up to 270km per hour, expected to hit southernmost subtropical island chain early Tuesday, possibly reaching mainland Japan by Wednesday
headline: Super-typhoon Neoguri approaches Japan's Okinawa islands

standfirst: A powerful typhoon batters the southern Japanese islands of Okinawa on Tuesday. This television footage shows the effects of the 120mph winds and storm surges of Neoguri, with people living in low-lying areas being told to leave their homes. Toppled buildings and trees can be seen and people seek shelter as winds pick up in the Okinawan capital of Naha
headline: Typhoon Neoguri batters Japan's Okinawa islands – video

standfirst: RNC chair Reince Priebus says Cleveland 'offers great stepping stone to the White House' after Ohio city beats Dallas challenge
headline: Cleveland wins race to host 2016 Republican national convention

standfirst: Some direct flights to US will require passengers to show cellphones, as authorities work to counter threat of explosives
headline: US-bound passengers may have to switch on mobile phones for security

standfirst: Joko 'Jokowi' Widodo claims his party has won Indonesia's toughly-fought presidential election on Wednesday. He makes the claim as his rival, the ex-general Prabowo Subianto, also claims victory in the vote. He appeals for all Indonesians to respect the results amid concerns that violence will break out between each candidate's supporters when the result is finalised
headline: Indonesian presidential candidate Joko Widodo claims election victory - video

standfirst: Ex-general Prabowo Subianto claims he has won Indonesia's presidential election, shortly after his rival Joko Widodo makes the same statement. Both men have announced victory in the closely-fought race, which is the country's third direct presidential election. Prabowo's speech was broadcast across Indonesia on state television
headline: Prabowo Subianto claims victory in Indonesia's presidential election - video

standfirst: BND president orders analysis of agency's communications for irregularities, and foreign minister to meet John Kerry
headline: German spy agency searches for more moles after US breach

standfirst: Business booms for sellers of traditional aphrodisiacs meant to ensure marital stability in conservative country
headline: Fish sperm potions and camel's milk concoctions keep love alive in Nigeria

standfirst: Australia's immigration minister, Scott Morrison, attends the commissioning ceremony of two refurbished gunboats given to Sri Lanka by Australia, standing alongside the country's president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, at the ceremony at a naval base in Colombo on Wednesday. 'Today is a symbol of the strong partnership that exists between Australia and Sri Lanka in dealing with people smuggling,' Morrison said. 'The message for anyone who is thinking that they can get to Australia illegally by boat is that the way is closed.'
headline: Scott Morrison attends gunboat commissioning ceremony in Sri Lanka – video

standfirst: Four people were hospitalised on the first day of Spain's San Fermin bull run, a daily race through the narrow, cobbled streets of Pamplona that forms part of the northern city's week-long festival. Runners tore through the streets to avoid the fighting bulls, and one participant was gored in the thigh, while the other three suffered fractures
headline: Four hospitalised in Pamplona bull run - video

standfirst: Eugene de Kock was sentenced in 1996 to two life terms for murder and other crimes as head of police death squad
headline: South Africa's apartheid-era assassin 'Prime Evil' denied parole

standfirst: Police say supporters were victims of illegal ring that demanded money in return for false promises of jobs
headline: Hundreds of Ghanaian football fans claim asylum in Brazil

standfirst: Twitter, Vine and Facebook feeds are offering jokes, solidarity and helpful tips for Muslims fasting through the month of Ramadan
headline: #RamadanProblems? Now there's a hashtag for that

standfirst: Karyn Parsons, who played Hilary Banks, seeks donations for Sweet Blackberry project, which shares stories of African American achievement
headline: Fresh Prince star aims to brings story of dancer Janet Collins to the screen

standfirst: Hollywood names have been taking advantage of France's notoriously strict privacy laws in 'forum shopping' phenomenon
headline: Scarlett Johansson is just latest A-list star to look for privacy in French courts

standfirst: He once owned 200 newspapers, headed the Heinz corporation and invented Kerrygold but the midas touch has finally failed Tony O'Reilly
headline: Tony O'Reilly: once Ireland's richest man, faces having to sell his homes

standfirst: Politicians say a statue of Mahatma Gandhi will be unveiled in Parliament Square in London. In India to meet the country's new prime minister, they say the statue will be a 'monument of the friendship between Britain and India' and say his  lessons of peace between communities and non-violent protests are as relevant today as they were in his own time. Britain will put up a statue to the father of the world's largest democracy in 'the most prominent place that we can'
headline: George Osborne and William Hague announce new statue of Gandhi during visit to India – video

standfirst: Revelation contrasts markedly with White House efforts to distance itself from UK government pressure to destroy disks
headline: NSA chief knew of Snowden file destruction by Guardian in UK

standfirst: Typhoon Neoguri has hit Japan's southern islands with gusts of up to 110mph before weakening and heading on to the mainland. Instagram users reveal their experiences
headline: Japan's typhoon Neoguri: what is it like inside the storm?

standfirst: Roman Seleznev, son of politician known for anti-American outbursts, arrested in Maldives on suspicion of hacking activities
headline: Russia hits out at 'kidnapping' of MP's son by US secret service

standfirst: Accused reportedly works 'in military', as Berlin still reels after intelligence agent was accused of working for CIA last week
headline: Second German government worker suspected of spying for US

standfirst: Development marks attitude change of militants, who previously allowed medics into region but now suspect them of spying
headline: Afghan Taliban bans polio vaccination teams from southern Helmand

standfirst: Host nation wakes up to worst football hangover in six decades, but analysts are split over its impact on Dilma Rousseff's re-election campaign
headline: Brazil's World Cup run is over but political ramifications still unclear

standfirst: Nick Xenophon, independent senator, takes to the Guardian Australia whiteboard to explain how the Senate works. 'Just bear with me,' he starts. 'Think of it like a big Rubik's Cube and you can't quite get it together.' Based on his primer, it looks like it's going to be a long parliament
headline: Nick Xenophon explains the Senate: ‘basically it's a schemozzle’ - whiteboard explainer video

standfirst: Scott Morrison confirmed 41 asylum seekers have been handed over to Sri Lanka's military after being processed at sea, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation said.  But Morrison refused to discuss the whereabouts of another 153 asylum seekers on another boat believed to be facing the same fate. During a radio interview before the injunction was granted on Monday, Morrison dismissed critics of the government's policy of handing asylum seekers to the Sri Lankan Navy at sea.
headline: Scott Morrison refuses to discuss the whereabouts of other 153 asylum seekers - video

standfirst: The transport secretary announces changes to airport security rules in which some passengers on unspecified routes will be required to prove that mobile devices are in working order. Patrick McLoughlin says people must co-operate with the new measures to keep delays to a minimum. The tightening of security comes in response to a 'credible threat' announced by the US Transportation Security Administration
headline: New airport security measures: 'co-operation will reduce delays' - video

standfirst: Laws on listing all ingredients on the labels of bottles mean illicit wine wallahs and big importers are running dry
headline: India's new alcohol labelling laws leave importers needing a drink

standfirst: Decision by state of Utah sets up prospect of a definitive ruling on the constitutionality of same-sex marriage in the United States
headline: Utah to appeal same-sex marriage ruling to US supreme court

standfirst: Soviet minister who was the diplomatic face of Gorbachev's policies during the cold war has died after a long illness
headline: Georgia's former president Eduard Shevardnadze dies aged 86

standfirst: 'Sportsmen's act', which also relaxes ammunition regulations, gains support from Democrats in key Republican states
headline: Senate passes vote to promote shooting on public land by 82 to 12

standfirst: Authorities advise 500,000 to evacuate as 155mph winds batter the Okinawan coasts
headline: Japan braces for worst storm in years as typhoon Neoguri approaches

standfirst: Russia's president has agreed to new talks aimed at resolving the conflict in eastern Ukraine, and has renounced the right to use military force in the country. Balázs Jarábik explains why
headline: Putin's Ukraine U-turn: why it makes sense for Russia to allow Kiev victory

standfirst: Highest 24-hour death toll since president ended brief ceasefire includes 19 troops killed in rocket attack near Russian border
headline: 23 Ukrainian troops killed in clashes with separatists

standfirst: As Transformers becomes China's biggest ever box office smash the US film studios are aiming to reel in Chinese audiences in their millions
headline: Hollywood zooms in on China's film market

standfirst: More questions surface over the use of Diego Garcia atoll for secret CIA flights to 'black sites'
headline: Remote Indian Ocean island holds key to understanding UK role in rendition

standfirst: The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, shows a noticeable limp as he walks on to stage and back off again at an event marking 20 years since the death of his grandfather, Kim Il-sung, the regime's founder. North Korean media material is highly choreographed and vetted – anything showing a weakness on the part of the leader is usually screened out of official coverage
headline: Kim Jong-un limps at anniversary event - video

standfirst: Senators react to the news that Australian border protection officials have handed back 41 Sri Lankan nationals, including four Tamils, over to Sri Lankan authorities in a transfer at sea. With Greens Christine Milne and Sarah Hanson-Young, Labor's Doug Cameron and Sam Dastyari and Independent Nick Xenophon.
headline: Handing back Tamils is ‘disturbing’ and ‘disgraceful’ - video

standfirst: From supercomputers to smartphones, technology could play greater role in combating spread of disease in west Africa
headline: Doctors look to technology in Ebola battle

standfirst: Hamid Karzai buckles amid mounting political crisis after pledging no foreign involvement in the election
headline: Afghanistan president Karzai backs UN plan to check votes for fraud

standfirst: Labor senator Penny Wong accuses Tony Abbott's government of arrogance using the Senate 'as a plaything' in its efforts to cut short the debate on the carbon tax repeal bills. The government failed by one vote in its attempt to guillotine the debate. Wong accused the government of trying to schedule the Senate vote around prime minister Tony Abbott's media appearances.
headline: Penny Wong lambasts 'arrogant' Abbott government's push to gag carbon debate - video

standfirst: Winner of the vote cannot be declared until election organisers finish checks following allegations of voting fraud
headline: Ashraf Ghani takes million-vote lead in Afghan presidential poll

standfirst: Row erupts as information minister backs decision to pulp all copies of book about male penguin couple following complaints
headline: Singapore libraries to destroy copies of gay penguin book

standfirst: Trailblazers including the Prettiots and Cibo Matto challenge male domination with canny use of social media to break out from an underground scene
headline: Golden age for all-female bands as they storm the Big Apple's bars and clubs

standfirst: Pope Francis issues a strong condemnation of child abuse within the Roman Catholic Church and begs forgiveness from those violated by church leaders. He compares abuse within the church to a 'sacrilegious cult' and says those responsible 'sacrificed [the children] to the idol of their own concupiscence'. It is his strongest condemnation yet of the way in which the church handled its abuse crisis
headline: Pope Francis compares paedophile priests to 'sacrilegious cult' - video

standfirst: Customer demand for legal, recreational marijuana looks set to exhaust retail stores' small supply of state-sanctioned pot
headline: Marijuana sales kick off in Washington state – but sellers are in short supply

standfirst: Rulings this week in Utah and Colorado have challenged the supreme court to definitively on the status of same-sex marriage
headline: Gay marriage in the US: what's the legal status?

standfirst: Washington stores opened their doors on Tuesday to sell cannabis legally for the first time. Here's what you need to know
headline: Marijuana in Washington state: where, when, and how much?

standfirst: The prime minister says the security services need to listen to someone's phone and read their emails to stop terrorist plots; to do this the government relies on help from internet and telephone companies. The new laws he introduces strengthen their powers to do this, he says, and will also help in the fight against child abuse and other serious crimes. He says he 'will not  stand by' and watch foreign companies become less willing to share private information with the government
headline: David Cameron explains why new surveillance laws are needed and what they will allow – video

standfirst: Legislation aims to shore up powers requiring phone and internet companies to retain and hand over data to security services
headline: Surveillance law wins cross-party support but critics claim stitch-up

standfirst: Clergy and mayor defy pope's attack on mafia by reportedly diverting church parade past mobster under house arrest
headline: Inquiry opens into Calabrian church's 'homage' to 'Ndrangheta mafia boss

standfirst: Walter Eagle Tail, 47, died at a hospital on Thursday after attempts to save him at the scene failed, police said
headline: South Dakota man dies after choking during hot-dog eating contest

standfirst: Tamil asylum seekers on board a boat intercepted by Australian authorities will not be sent to Sri Lanka without 72 hours' written notice to the high court, government says
headline: Australia forced into concession over Sri Lanka asylum seekers

standfirst:
• Bipartisan criticism of attempts to tackle immigration crisis
• Obama uses Texas speech to say: 'I'm the guy doing his job'
headline: White House faces Senate opposition over $3.7bn for child migrant crisis

headline: Tourist snap: crocodile on the loose in Crete sparks visitor rush to island

standfirst: Alexander Borodai, leader of Donetsk 'republic', and 10 others face travel bans and asset freezes as clashes continue in east
headline: EU imposes sanctions on more Ukraine rebels

standfirst: Parliamentary committee set up to resolve row over number of shows country singer can play at Croke Park is postponed
headline: Irish government under pressure to save Garth Brooks concerts

standfirst: Prime minister offers review of intercept legislation to secure cross-party support for emergency surveillance laws
headline: David Cameron makes concessions to rush through snooping law

standfirst: Report into Bank of China foreign exchange programme surprises many, as investigations into state enterprises are rare
headline: China's state TV accuses central bank of money laundering

standfirst: Move comes in response to two reported cases of suspected US spying in Germany
headline: Germany asks top US intelligence official to leave country over spy row

headline: Public will see 1918 footage of George V visiting airbase for first time

standfirst: Equatorial Guinea has one of the worst human rights records on the continent, overseen by Africa’s longest serving dictator. Simon Allison met Tutu Alicante, one of the few Equatorial Guineans fighting for equality
headline: Equatorial Guinea: One man's fight against dictatorship

standfirst: Waterway is hoped to lift central American country out of poverty but critics warn of legal, environmental and economic pitfalls
headline: Nicaragua unveils 173-mile route of £23bn canal to rival Panama

standfirst: Saturday night offers spectacular sunset through Manhattan's cross streets, where sun aligns perfectly with the horizon
headline: Manhattanhenge: New Yorkers get ready for 'rare and beautiful sight'

standfirst: Trading in Banco Espírito Santo suspended after shares dive as investors fear prospect of new eurozone trouble
headline: Portuguese bank fears hit stock markets

standfirst: The US spy agency's writing manual has been leaked. What does it teach us about penning truly great secret communiques?
headline: The CIA style guide goes online: now you can learn to write like a spy

standfirst: Chinese novellist turns himself in after saying he should be treated like friends held over 25th anniversary commemoration
headline: Author Murong Xuecun summoned by police over Tiananmen Square event

standfirst: Rights groups say claim that records of Diego Garcia flights  are missing due to water damage 'smacks of cover-up'
headline: Files on UK role in CIA rendition accidentally destroyed, says minister

standfirst: James Prigoff one of the people suing over 'McCarthy era' tactics after the FBI monitored him for photographing public art
headline: Five plaintiffs sue after being targeted in US 'suspicious activity' database

standfirst: News of attempt to target people who had applied for security clearances comes as John Kerry attends Sino-American summit
headline: Chinese hackers break into US federal government employee database

standfirst: More than 186 million Indonesians will head to the polls on 9 July to choose a new leader in a presidential election analysts say is too close to call. Jakarta governor Joko 'Jokowi' Widodo and former general Prabowo Subianto are running neck and neck to be the new leader of the world's third-largest democracy
headline: Indonesian presidential election ‘too close to call’ - video

standfirst: Bild newspaper says interior ministry emphasising the need for effective counter-intelligence in wake of arrest of BND staffer
headline: Germany to escalate counter-espionage efforts in wake of US spying allegations

standfirst:
Animal rights group Peta has released secretly filmed video of cruel acts it says took place in 19 shearing sheds in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. The footage shows sheep being roughly handled, punched in the face and stamped upon. One sheep was beaten with a hammer while another was shown having a deep cut crudely sewn up.
• Read the full story
WARNING: This video contains graphic images of animal abuse
headline: Sheep beaten with a hammer, punched and thrown around by shearers  - video

standfirst:
Protesters in the Sydney suburb of Redfern say they will stand in front of bulldozers to stop developers changing the culturally significant area. The area known as the Block is set to be redeveloped by the Aboriginal Housing Company, which says commercial and student accommodation will be built before affordable Indigenous housing.
• Read the full story
headline: Redfern 'Block' protesters vow to stop developers moving in – video

standfirst: Old boys protest after Aitchison College governors in Lahore say they will no longer favour sons of rich and powerful
headline: Alumni rage over admissions reform at elite Pakistan English-language school

standfirst: A visit to an ostrich farm near Nairobi offers a close-up view of a bird second only to the cheetah for speed
headline: Letter from Kenya: fast food

standfirst: A railway bridge near the Ukrainian city of Donestsk lies in ruin after it was blown up on Monday, along with two other key transport routes in the region. A railway worker says the explosion shook a nearby village. It was not clear who blew up the rail and road bridges, but it comes after recent withdrawals by separatist fighters in the area
headline: Donetsk railway bridge explosion rattles nearby village - video

standfirst:
Flat Man is Christchurch's very own superhero. Emerging after the city's earthquakes he provided food packages to those most in need. He now visits schools, teaching kids to be their own superhero by being kind, generous and looking out for each other, as well as teaming up with other charities to help spread joy and laughter in a city that has been through so much. He's the hero Christchurch deserves and the one it needs right now

Click here to see the full video 'I am Flat Man'

Click here to follow him on Facebook
headline: Flat Man: the superhero New Zealand deserves – video

standfirst:
• Defense Department spent millions to research social networks
• Studies focused on Occupy and Middle East protests
• Projects also analysed memes, celebrities and disinformation
headline: US military studied how to influence Twitter users in Darpa-funded research

standfirst: There is no need to rush through legislation but it offers chance to bring rise of surveillance state under democratic control
headline: 'Emergency' is bogus but surveillance law could prove rare liberal moment

standfirst: Campaigners led by ACLU say unaccompanied children have not been able to find lawyers and will not have a fair hearing
headline: Child migrants facing deportation denied basic rights, lawsuit claims

standfirst: Previously classified documents show federal agents continued to monitor Mandela and ANC even after his release from prison
headline: FBI monitored Nelson Mandela in 1990s over perceived communist threat

standfirst: Agreement, which stipulates that Cuba must still repay $3.2bn over 10 years, comes as President Vladimir Putin prepares for Havana trip. The Moscow Times reports
headline: Russia writes off $32bn Cuban debt in show of brotherly love

standfirst: Elliot Sperling believes his support for Uighur academic Ilham Tohti is reason authorities ordered him to return to US
headline: US academic barred from China after speaking out over detained scholar

headline: Richard Mellon Scaife obituary

standfirst: President of Georgia and Soviet foreign minister who promoted perestroika during Mikhail Gorbachev's time in power
headline: Eduard Shevardnadze obituary

standfirst: Hundreds gather in New Delhi after government announced 14% increase in effort to get ailing service back on track
headline: Indian railway fare rises spark protests

standfirst: Residents of the eastern Ukrainian city of Luhansk and the town of Maryinka clean up the damage on Saturday after the Ukrainian military shelled parts of the region. The military says the shelling was in retaliation for a rebel missile strike that killed 30 Ukrainian soldiers on Friday
headline: Eastern Ukrainian cities shelled by the military in a night of violence - video

standfirst: Incident occured in village of Cherry Willingham, near Lincoln, and involved train heading for Immingham docks
headline: Two people killed by freight train at footpath crossing

standfirst: UN refugee agency says it is 'deeply concerned' about transfer of Tamils, who fear torture or death at hands of Sri Lanka police
headline: Australia accused of breaking law after returning asylum seekers to Sri Lanka

standfirst: The Ukrainian government promises severe punishment for those responsible for a rocket attack on Ukrainian troops that killed at least 19 servicemen. Zoryan Shkiryak, Ukrainian interior ministry spokesperson, says up to 30 servicemen were killed and promised swift justice. 'They will be punished, destroyed or captured and will answer [for their crimes] according to the Ukrainian law,' he says
headline: Ukrainian government promises swift justice for military deaths - video

standfirst: Some witnesses reported that people leapt from the upper floors of apartment building in Lowell as it was engulfed in flames
headline: Seven dead after apartment fire in Massachusetts town

standfirst: Presidential contender stops short of announcing parallel cabinet after US warnings, while rival Ghani hints at unity government
headline: Afghan poll crisis deepens as Abdullah rejects official results and claims victory

standfirst: Low-lying south Florida, at the front line of climate change in the US, will be swallowed as sea levels rise. Astonishingly, the population is growing, house prices are rising and building goes on. The problem is the city is run by climate change deniers
headline: Miami, the great world city, is drowning while the powers that be look away

standfirst: For years, Beijing has sent North Korean defectors back to their country despite the threat of harsh punishments on their return. Now, the UN's Commission of Inquiry on human rights is renewing efforts to change that, says Witness to Transformation
headline: UN seeks to persuade China to end forced repatriations to North Korea

standfirst: Obama administration plan includes fast-track deportations and ankle bracelets to handle backlog at southern border
headline: White House seeks $3.7bn in extra funding to address child migrant crisis

standfirst: Abdullah Abdullah says he may form his own cabinet and claims victory in crisis-hit poll after preliminary official results give large lead to his rival Ashraf Ghani
headline: Afghan presidential candidate hints at parallel government

standfirst: Civil liberties groups may withdraw support from Employment Nondiscrimination Act (Enda) over religion addition
headline: Obama pressured on religious exemptions after Hobby Lobby decision

standfirst: John Kerry has condemned computer espionage at meetings in Beijing amid new reports of Chinese hacking of US offices
headline: Kerry hits out at Chinese cyber-spying

standfirst: Germany already taking counter-measures as CIA maintains silence over alleged recruitment of German intelligence official
headline: White House on the back foot over CIA role in German spying scandal

standfirst: The brother of jailed al-Jazeera journalist Peter Greste says he is encouraged by recent comments from the country's president over the trial. President Abdel Fatah al-Sisi on Sunday told Egyptian media he regretted the case went to trial and wished the men had been deported instead. Greste says he is heartened by the comments and hopes for a positive resolution to his brother's case
headline: Brother of jailed al-Jazeera journalist 'heartened' by Egyptian president's comments - video

standfirst:
Friday is World Population Day. How good is your knowledge of all the other people on the planet? Take our quiz to find out

All figures are from the UN population division's estimates
headline: World Population Day: how much do you know about our crowded world? Take our quiz

standfirst: Ex-husband of Iqbal al-Hilli died of a heart attack in the US on the same day as deadly 2012 attack in French Alps, police say
headline: Alps shootings: murdered woman's 'secret' ex-husband died on same day

standfirst: Activists claim fashion mogul Peter Nygard's proposed development risks environmental damage to beaches
headline: Sean Connery joins Bahamas campaign to stop billionaire developing mansion

standfirst:
Gangster and drug dealer Abderrozak Benarabe, or Big A as he's known on the streets of Copenhagen, made a deal with God that if his brother was delivered from cancer he would redeem his criminal ways and go to fight jihad in Syria alongside his fellow foreign fighters and child soldiers under 16. Director Nagieb Khaja followed Big A from his gang in Denmark into brutally-intense battle on the jihadi frontline in Syria and back to Copenhagen to amass and smuggle supplies to the fighters across the Greek-Turkish border

WARNING: This film contains scenes of death and injury in battle and testimony from the family of an alleged victim of torture. Some viewers may find these scenes upsetting
headline: European jihadi: the Danish gangster who joined the Syrian frontline – video

standfirst: The Japanese prime minister made a historic address to the Australian parliament on Tuesday, offering his condolences for the loss of life in the second world war and vowing never to allow a repeat of 'the horrors of the past'. Shinzo Abe underlined his desire to strengthen Japan's ties with Australia, saying both nations loved peace, freedom, democracy, human rights and the rule of law.
headline: Shinzo Abe addresses Australian parliament and offers ‘sincere condolences’ for second world war horrors - video

standfirst:
• At least 80 people shot in Chicago, 14 fatally, over holiday
• Chicago police superintendent puts blame on lax gun laws
headline: Gun violence flares up across US in bloody Fourth of July weekend

standfirst: The US state department defends US-German relations after a top US intelligence official was asked to leave Germany on Thursday, in connection with investigations into suspected US spying in the country. German Chancellor Angela Merkel said spying on allies was a waste of energy and that priorities should include dealing with challenges in Syria and fighting terrorism, and that confidence between allies should be strengthened
headline: German relationship with US 'extremely important', says state department - video

standfirst: Rosanell Eaton, 93, testifies on the experience of voting in 1940 and says same battle for black voting rights is being fought today
headline: North Carolina voter recalls Jim Crow tactics in testimony against new law
Why our boycott campaign against Israel makes sense

standfirst: CCTV has emerged purporting to show the moment an Isis suicide bomber detonates in the northern Iraq city of Kirkuk, killing seven people. The footage, shot on June 25, shows a man being approached by two Kurdish security guards in Rahim Awa, before a large explosion is seen in the street. Violence in Iraq shows no sign of subsiding as militants continue to battle Iraqi forces and cause further divisions in the country's government
headline: CCTV allegedly shows moment suicide bomber detonates in Kirkuk - video

standfirst: Deployed in an attempt to protect southern Israeli towns from missiles and artillery shells launched from inside Gaza

headline: Iran needs greater uranium enrichment capacity, says Ayatollah Ali Khamenei

standfirst: Edward Snowden's lawyer in Germany says the NSA whistleblower wishes to return to the US in the 'medium to long term'. Wolfgang Kaleck says Snowden is living in 'relative safety' in Russia and avoiding any activities that threaten his security. Kaleck says Snowden wants the focus not to be on him as a person but rather the privacy issues at stake
headline: Edward Snowden wants to return to US in 'medium to long term', says lawyer – video

standfirst: Israeli airstrikes continue to shake Gaza on Wednesday, as militants keep up their rocket attacks into Israel. Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas says Israel is protecting its settlement policy, while Israeli prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu vows to intensify attacks on Hamas. There have been no reports of deaths in Israel, while in Palestinian territories almost 50 people, including children, have been killed and more than 450 injured, according to Gaza's health ministry
headline: Israeli airstrikes shake Gaza while Hamas persists with rocket attacks - video

standfirst: How Israel's air defence system is holding out despite extensive rocket fire from Gaza this week
headline: Iron Dome: Israel's 'game-changing' missile shield

standfirst: Palestinian medicas say more than 80 killed, while Obama offers to help broker ceasefire and rockets are fired from Lebanon
headline: Gaza death toll rises as Israel escalates aerial assault

standfirst: As Israeli air campaign continues, in a Palestinian district there is support for those firing rockets from Gaza
headline: Tensions high in East Jerusalem as violence escalates

standfirst: A house in Rafah, Gaza, is reduced to rubble on Friday morning after a fourth night of Israeli air strikes leaves more people dead. Palestinian officials say more than 80 people have been killed in the latest offensive, which Israel launched in response to Hamas firing rockets into the country. An Israeli military spokesman says the army hit more than 320 Hamas targets overnight
headline: Gaza: fourth night of Israeli air strikes leaves more dead - video

standfirst: Officials in Egypt stress they are providing humanitarian assistance to Palestinians and helping to end Gaza conflict
headline: Egypt opens border with Gaza to allow airstrike casualties in for medical care

standfirst: Israel escalated a punishing aerial offensive in Gaza for a third day, launching raids on more than 300 targets in response to rocket fire
headline: Israeli airstrikes shake Gaza – in pictures

standfirst: Paramedics in Gaza treat those wounded by Israeli air strikes on Monday. The armed wing of the Palestinian militant group Hamas says seven of its fighters died in a single strike near Rafah in southern Gaza. The Israeli military said the strikes are in response to rocket and mortar attacks on Israel on Sunday
headline: Paramedics in Gaza treat the wounded following Israeli air strikes - video

standfirst: The Israeli army continued airstrikes across Gaza on Wednesday as part of their 'operation protective edge'. The latest attacks follow a night of 160 airstrikes by israel. Gaza's health ministry now puts the Palestinian death toll from those strikes at 35. Israel is retaliating after Hamas launched rockets at Tel Aviv, so far injuring but not killing, civilians
headline: Israeli airstrikes continue over Gaza - video

standfirst: More than 100 have died – often women and children in their own homes – and food prices are rising fast as supplies dry up
headline: Ramadan in Gaza: life under missile-fire

standfirst: Black smoke is seen rising over the northern Gaza Strip following Israeli air strikes. Israel, which is intensifying its military operation against the Hamas-ruled strip and gathering tanks  at the border, says the strikes are in response to the hundreds of rockets launched from Gaza into Israel over the last few weeks, including 80 in one day. 'Our goal is the free the people of Israel from the threat of these incoming rockets,' says Mark Regev, spokesman for the Israeli prime minister
headline: Israel intensifies military operation against Gaza – video

standfirst: Air raid sirens ring out over Tel Aviv as Israel's military brings down a rocket fired at the city by Hamas. Israel has launched an offensive, in which 23 people were killed on Tuesday, following a string of rocket attacks from Palestinian territories. Three weeks of violence between Israel and Hamas been the bloodiest in the area since 2012
headline: Hamas fires rockets at Israel as violence continues - video

standfirst: As the number of Palestinians killed since Tuesday exceeds 120, Israel says it will continue its offensive in Gaza until Hamas militants are defeated. At least two disabled women were killed in Israeli shelling of a rehabilitation facility. The women are among 16 Palestinians reported to have died in Israeli air strikes early on Saturday morning
headline: Israel vows to continue bombarding Gaza as number of dead rises - video

standfirst: Palestinians say up to eight members of a single family, including children, among the dead as air strikes enter third day
headline: Israeli offensive in Gaza continues with at least 14 killed

standfirst: Palestinian mosque hit and two people at charity for disabled reported to be among latest victims of Operation Protective Edge
headline: Israel continues Gaza bombardment, pushing death toll past 120

standfirst: Family loses eight members and cafe full of football fans watching World Cup hit as IDF strikes 300 targets in one night
headline: Palestinians say death toll over 70 as Israel pounds Gaza with air raids

standfirst: Israel has hit hundreds of Hamas targets in Gaza, and the Palestinian death toll continues to rise. The UN's top human rights official has said the campaign may violate international laws prohibiting the targeting of civilians, and the US has offered to try to broker a truce
headline: Fourth day of Israeli air attack on Gaza – in pictures

standfirst: Palestinian youths launch a protest at an Israeli military base in Gaza, after IDF soldiers fired teargas canisters at them. The clashes, in the early hours of Wednesday morning, come after an Israeli offensive in Gaza left at least 25 people dead. Israel has warned of more strikes in response to Hamas launching rockets into the country
headline: Palestinian youths clash with Israeli soldiers in Gaza - video

Army source says 'we are entering a long operation' as country responds to sustained rocket attacks and teenagers' murder

• Live updates - Israel steps up offensive
headline: Israel steps up Gaza offensive and prepares for possible ground invasion

standfirst: Israeli PM authorises escalation of offensive as Palestinian death toll rises and rocket attacks from Gaza target Tel Aviv
headline: Netanyahu instructs Israeli military to intensify assault on Gaza

standfirst: Rockets target city for first time since Israel's 2012 war with Hamas, prompting  thousands of residents to seek shelter
headline: Bomb shelters prepared in Jerusalem after rockets are fired from Gaza

standfirst: Israel continues its attack on Gaza on Thursday morning, with buildings on fire after having been shelled. Gaza's health ministry claims that 75 people have been killed and 535 more injured during three days of military action. Israel's Operation Protective Edge is a response to Hamas's rockets attacks on the country
headline: Buildings blaze as Gaza comes under fire by Israel for third day – video

standfirst: Paralysis of Arab League members over conflict as much a target of anger across region as Israel and US support for it
